user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_StoreRetval:
```c
bool UT_StoreRetval(UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize, UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre)
{
    /* Copy the value based on width, so it will be properly extended, if applicable:
     * - all numeric values need to be aligned per endianness of the host
     * - signed ints must be sign-extended,
     * - single-precision floating points will be extended to double-precision
     *
     * Pointers must all be the expected size, however.
     */
    switch (UT_GENRE_SIZE(ValueGenre, ValueSize))
    {
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int8)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int8 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int16)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int16 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int32)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int32 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int64)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int64 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(float)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((float const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((double const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_POINTER, sizeof(void *)):
            Buf->Ptr = *((void *const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        default:
            return UtAssert_Failed("Cannot store return value - ValueSize not valid");
    }

    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_StoreRetval:
typedef union UT_RetvalBuf
{
    uint8          Raw[8];
    const void *   IndirectPtr;
    void *         Ptr;
    UT_IntReturn_t Integer;
    double         FloatingPt;
} UT_RetvalBuf_t
...
typedef enum UT_ValueGenre
{
    UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE  = 0, /**< The nature of the value is opaque, reference is stored directly (NOT copied!) */
    UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER = 1, /**< The value is an integer and may be converted to integers of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT   = 2, /**< The value is a floating point and may be converted to floats of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_POINTER = 3  /**< The value is a pointer and should only be used to fulfill a pointer return */
} UT_ValueGenre_t
...
#define UT_GENRE_SIZE(g, s) (((size_t)g<<8)|s)
...
typedef int8_t    int8
...
typedef int16_t   int16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef int64_t   int64
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The pointer case in UT_StoreRetval performs a cast/dereference involving pointer-to-pointer types and assigns into a non-const void * member; this should be investigated for lost or improperly propagated const-qualification per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. The union member declaration of Ptr (void * Ptr) is also relevant because it stores a non-const pointer where a const-qualified pointer might be appropriate.

Other fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13:
- The ValuePtr parameter is declared as const void * (it preserves const qualification on the incoming data). 
- All integer and floating-point casts explicitly use const-qualified pointer types (e.g., (int8 const *), (float const *), (double const *)), so they preserve const on the pointee and are not suspect for this rule.
- The union also contains IndirectPtr declared as const void * (already const-qualified), so it conforms with the rule.
- The function parameter Buf (UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf) is an output buffer that must be modified; therefore it being a non-const pointer is appropriate and not a violation of Rule 8.13.
- Other typedefs and the UT_GENRE_SIZE macro do not affect pointer const-qualification in this context.
